Health & Safety for Licensed Child Care Providers, Module C
Section 3: Emergency Preparedness, Response, & Recovery

Categories of Emergency Hazards

Emergencies fall under different categories. Here are some examples of hazards that fall under each category of Emergency Hazards.

Please hover or tab over the cards below to find out more about the categories of Emergency Hazards.

Natural

The most common ones under Natural Hazards in our state are fire, floods, tornados, winter storms, thunderstorms and excessive heat.

Technological

Technological hazards include items like industrial explosions, power outages, gas leaks, dam failures and hazardous materials.

Biological

Infectious disease, toxic materials, chemical spills, and contaminated food fall under Biological hazards.

Man-Made

Man-made disasters involve hazards like active shooters, bomb threats, terrorism, intruders, criminal activity, and missing, lost, or abducted children.
